title: Let's figure out what we ACTUALLY don't like about the Boards
body:
Let's be honest: If you set the sorting to **Recent** and use **Chronological View,** the boards are *functionally* identical to old GD (albeit with a few areas that need work. \*cough\* quoting \*cough\*)

So, what is the actual issue? It's how they *look.* SO...

#ITT: Leave what you do / don't like about Boards' LOOK AND FEEL.

Let's figure out what needs changing, so we can set the Boards team to work ;)

Yours,
Hyrum Graff

After being on this board for many months and at the start of those months having a similar opinion to you, I can honestly say that I have yet to see any sort of constructive (which is, I think, the better word here, not "factual" since facts only support your opinion, not prove it) posts completely closed straight away. In fact, I see *more* constructive discussion about UP/OP champions that don't immediately devolve into "NERF PLZ RITO" and the like, which I prefer. 

The old forums were ok, I like the chronological style and I occasionally look at the "Recent Threads" tab, but let's be honest: this system is designed to make the more constructive, more discussion-oriented conversations more visible. When that doesn't happen is when people are more interested in complaining loudly than having an actual discussion, so the discussion was probably doomed from the start, no matter what format you use.

Also, one very important thing the old forums didn't have: **a report button**. See someone spamming the same thread over and over? Report those suckers!

The required coding can be done in a single if statement regardless of if it is a blended option or not.

i.e.:   score = (numVotes + numComments > 10 && secondsSinceCreation > 600) ? (upVotes - downVotes) : "??");

That line of code means:
If the number of votes + the number of comments is greater than 10 AND it has been at least 10 minutes since the post was created, display the score.  If not, display "??".

So, this particular statement imposes a minimum incubation of 10 minutes.

Hello Rito staff member, as a web developer of 7+ years who runs my own business I believe I can help you with some free design consulting.  So here is my professional as well as personal feedback, I will separate the two:

Professional Feedback:
1) Your page loads, then each post loads through javascript.  This is a very poor design decision for multiple reasons.
1a) It makes caching systems difficult.  Instead of being able to cache an entire page, and deal with one request for that page and the images/css/javascript on that page, you have to make caches for every ajax call or simply leave them uncached.
1b) This increases load on the server considerably, making your site scale worse, which for a high traffic site like yours is a bad direction to take.
1c) It confuses the user who loads the page and sees empty comments that suddenly appear.  
1d) It is slow to load the thing people most come to see, the post content itself.  It should be reversed, if anything, people want the content not later, but now.

2) Aesthetically, as some form of art or medal or cool graphic, the boards look freakin sweet!  But unfortunately for you, it's not a cool graphic or medal or strictly art, it is a web page and as such usability, readability and most of all functionality take precedence to looking great.  Here's where you go wrong on that:
2a) Dark backgrounds with light text are scientifically proven to be worse, your reading rate goes down, your conversion rate in ecommerce goes down, your share rate goes down and thus your overall popularity plummets too.  A poll here: http://www.webdesignerdepot.com/2009/08/the-dos-and-donts-of-dark-web-design/ says that 47% say the main cause of concern is readability.  And it's true.  With all the bad things about dark backgrounds with light text, you'd be best to stay entirely away from it at all.  You can have dark elements, dark backgrounds, etc.  But where there is text there should be light backgrounds with dark text, and the more they contrast the better.  That said if you are entirely set on having a dark background with light text, that article I linked has some good pointers you could follow.  For one you could have more whitespace for each character and make the contrast greater between the gold text and dark background.  But as a professional if you were my client I'd highly recommend you shelf the current design as an alternative theme for those who enjoy it and rework it so that there is at least where there is text, a light background with dark text.  Even if that's the only change you make it'd be well worth it.

Personal Feedback:
I don't think I'm alone in saying that the "best" view is not the best at all.  I get that as a company riot wants to be able to go through posts and read only what is "best" to save time as you have a lot of busy people.  And rather than hiring internal people to read it all and show only the best community responses you'd like that to be determined by the community.  But this poses several problems to me as a user and it is significant to me, tho maybe not everyone.  I don't like the best view, and even having chronological view... "best" is the default.   Meaning only me and a few others will see my post in a long thread and even if it is a good comment/post, it likely will never be upvoted, let alone read at all.  Which makes me either have to wait to be one of the first to post in a thread or just be discouraged from posting altogether, which isn't good for riot or me either, to be discouraging posting.  Boards should be warm and welcoming and even a bit hectic, not hostile and a competition upon which your every post is judged and sorted by mob rule.  Mob rule isn't very effective governing in real world scenarios.  And this is much more mob rule than democracy.

I think replies to comments should automatically collapsed and be more spaced apart so it look less like a wall of text.
I really like the way YouTube comments organizes replies. If you want to figure out more about what people think about a comment you can uncollapse it. That way you don't have trouble differentiating what a reply and a actual comment is.

I get the low-contrast benefits of the new boards, but I think it goes too far.  There needs to be at least a LITTLE bit more contrast between different interface elements to make things easier.  My brain has trouble dealing with it and it just makes me want to do something else the entire time lol.

Also, I strongly disagree with the push toward a fully democratic system where popularity wins.  Sometimes, popular things are wrong/bad, and unpopular things are right/good.  This system seems to *only* side with popularity, unless I misunderstand it.  I think it is unwise to do that, given the history of this community.

The stuff on the front page when sorting by "hot" is impacted by three things

- Rating (up/down votes - which are interpreted as "more people or less people should see this"
- Activity (How much discussion is there)
- Time (How fresh is the discussion)

In order for the system to be successful I think we have to really heavily develop a strong voting culture where people really understanding the impact of a vote.

I used to hate the color scheme, too, but after a couple weeks I started to like it much more. Give it a chance! Or don't, and you won't have to wait very long for a [new color scheme](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/site-feedback/6HqcPo0c-i-work-on-the-boards-ama?comment=0006).

While it may seem at first that "Hot" is purely democratic, it's actually possible to get a lot of visibility for your post, if you're willing to do a little work. By responding (with content) to every single comment thread, I was able to keep [this](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/gameplay-balance/zAfWqyEL-lets-talk-about-talon-and-give-him-back-a-healthy-silence) post on the front page for about 15 hours yesterday/today. Granted, with way more people posting now that old GD is gone, you won't be able to keep it there for as long, but there's also more people to see your post, so I think it should even out.
